groups.name: Book Lovers Hub
groups.description:
Welcome to the book club!
Each month we’ll be reading a compelling book, that is guaranteed to spark great conversations.

The requirements of our book picks are that they must be focused on personal development, happiness, career and balance. They are books that are actionable to help us improve our lives throughout the year.
We will add variety each month so you don’t feel like you are reading the same thing each month.

groupPost.text: Hi Ladies, I am new here. I want to read books in 2021 and beyond. I am counting on your help...

Thanks to @Rovingheights I have been enjoying my current read of Women and Leadership by Madam Ngozi Iwela and Julia Gillard. Chapter one painted a startling picture of the maleness of the world we live in, so I thought to share with you some really shocking gender gaps in the world you should know about

1. Only one woman vs 93 men have won the OSCAR for best director

2. Only 6.6% of fortune 500 CEOs are women

3. Only 6 of the FTSE 100 CEOs are women

4. Only 24% of people heard, read about or seen in news media are women

5. Globally for every dollar a man earns, a woman earns 63cents.

6. Serena Williams is the only woman on the 100 highest paid athlethes in the world today, and she is no 63

7. Nobel Prize award for Literature has been given to 101 men and only 15 women

8. Out of the 900 individuals who have won a Nobel prize, only 53 have been women

9. In artificial intelligence, women are an estimated 26% of the workforce, in engineering 15% and in cloud computing 12%

10. In the US only 2.7% of venture capital funding goes to companies founded solely by women

11. According to the world economic forum of the 3343 ministerial positions examined in 153 countries, only 21% were held by women.
It's another weekend! A good time to relax and read! How's our book going? What is your hit point thus far?

This week and beyond... OWN YOUR AMBITION!

Happy new week book lovers!
#mondaymotivation 
Excerpt from the book of the month, Women And Leadership.

#booklovers

Hello Book Lovers!

What book are you onto this week or would love to read? Share with us!

P.S Kindly vote for the book of the month (September) in the post below. Details will be finalized this week based on your votes and we kick off the reading journey fully next Monday. 

Enjoy a fine week.

Book Of The Month:

Hey book lovers! September is almost here and we have an interesting line up of books to pick as our book of the month. Here they are! Don't forget to vote for them in the comments.


1 Dear Alaere: Alaere Benson is your typical modern, professional woman in search of that elusive work-life balance and societal acceptance in Lagos. This is a fiction book that talks about navigating life as a career woman. From working for a multinational company to being married and more.Through Alaere’s dairy, she navigates a world most of us can only dream of with a familiarity that introduces her as a voice that needs to be heard.


2 Nice Girls Don't Get the corner office:

Unconscious Mistakes Women Make That Sabotage Their Careers. This book teaches you how to eliminate these unconscious mistakes that could be holding you back and offers invaluable coaching tips that can easily be incorporated into your social and business skills. Stop making "nice girl" errors that can become career pitfalls


3 Women and Leadership:

An inspirational and practical book written by two high-achieving women, sharing the experience and advice of some of our most extraordinary women leaders, in their own words. From their broad experience on the world stage in politics, economics and global not-for-profits, Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala and Julia Gillard have some strong ideas about the impact of gender on the treatment of leaders. Women and Leadership takes a consistent and comprehensive approach to teasing out what is different for women leaders


Now let’s vote!

Your greatness is limited only by the investments you make in yourself.


Embrace your fears to skyrocket your growth. You need to recognize that fear will come in one of two ways. You either feel like people will reject you or that you will fail. And you’ll have to learn how to handle both to come out on top. 


Above statement is an Excerpt from the book Be Average Or Be Obsessed by Grant Cardone.


Today is a great opportunity to kick-start the week and feel motivated to tackle anything that comes our way. 


If we change our perspective, everything else changes. And what better to do that with than a good book? What book are you reading this week?


#BookMotivationMonday

First book for the month of August, done and dusted!!!!! 

Recently, I have been having a lot of dreams- about 8 since June and today. Many of these dreams were repetitive. 

So I knew, I needed to get into the practice of taking my dreams seriously. This book really helped. 

What book have you been reading? Take a picture and share

Oh ye book lovers let's jump on this ship!

How do you master the art of reading? While we anticipate your reading tips here are some tips too.


First, you need to know why you are reading at any time. Are you reading for relaxation, entertainment, information, for deepening your mind or gaining more insights? The goal that you set for yourself when you’re going to read any text-whether you’re reading for entertainment, information or understanding will determine the way in which you read. 


Focus on chapter/section at a time. You can't read the whole book at once. Especially if the book is 'gigantic' it could be a discouragement to finish and we mentally tell ourselves 'oh I can't finish this book'. So focus on the book chapter by chapter. You could also leverage the 80%/20% rule. Many times,not everything in the book is needed so you could start with skimming through and understanding the thought process before settling down to it. Read for key ideas.


Now you are clear on the intent of reading at that time, Make the Book Your Own! While reading a book, you should be holding a conversation with the author, asking questions, making comments, and so on.

Make the book your own.


Find your right reading strategy. Are you a visual or auditory person? You can download audible and other apps to help you read out your books. Do you prefer paperback to digital books? You need to identify what state or condition allows you to flow.



We trust this has been helpful. Share your thoughts.

Hi guys. Hope your day has been good. So I'm trying to get into the habit of reading books and have downloaded Audible from PlayStore. 
It would be nice to see posts from people who have already mastered the habit of reading books so that the rest of us can be encouraged. Let us make this place lively please. Thanks
Hi guys! I set a goal to read two books a month...who wants to join me?? Type yes here and I'll share the list...feel free to share a book recommendation

5 books our founder recommends for career women.


So yes we know sometimes our reading habit goes down the drain, so we thought, what better way to get back on track than by creating an awesome, inspirational list of books? Here are 5 books you should definitely order for.


1. Presence by Amy Cuddy.

This books helps you bring your boldest self to your biggest challenges. Ready to make the best out of every opportunity? Then, this is a must read.


2. Deep Work by Cal Newport.

Ready to focus on your focus as banish distraction? Read this.


3. The Secret Thoughts Of Successful Women by Valerie Young.

Tired of imposter syndrome stopping you from achieving your goals? Read this!


4. Own it...the power of women at work by Sallie Crawcheck.

This book will show you how to take your seat at the table.


5.So good they can't ignore you by Cal Newport

Read this to find out skills that would make you indispensable and how to develop them.


Let me know if you have read any of these books or which you would like to read first!

What is the best book you have read so far in 2020?

Share with us.

Share Your Book Recommendation.

Did you read a career/personal development book that really impacted your life? 
Share it with us in the comments, the book title and author.

Title: Things Mentally Strong Women Don’t Do: Own Your Power, Channel Your Confidence, and Find Your Authentic Voice
 Author: Amy Morin.

Her latest book, 13 Things Mentally Strong Women Don’t Do, outlines the bad habits that women are more likely to engage in.
Cultural pressures, societal expectations and the subtle differences in the ways girls are raised are just a few of the factors that encourage women to engage in these unhealthy habits. 

Fortunately, recognizing those unhealthy habits is the first step in creating positive change so you can move forward toward reaching your greatest potential.

At the end of the day, it’s always important to build your mental muscle. Everyone has the ability to do this -- and there’s always room for improvement. So work smarter, not just harder, on becoming your strongest self. Give up the bad habits that are holding you back so you can take steps forward toward reaching your greatest potential.

Book Spotlight.

    - Title: The Pressure Cooker
    - Author: Nkiru Olumide Ojo
    - How To Buy:  Click here to purchase (For those in Nigeria.
      Others, please purchase via Amazon)
     - Book Discount: at the point of checkout, please apply the discount code -
       9to5chick

Can women have it all?
The book was worth the read, very detailed and apt.
Olumide-Ojo’s The Pressure Cooker: Lessons From A Woman At Work, is an attempt to answer questions about how women of her status have managed to combine their family, especially as mothers, and their career, and how she has moved forward in her industry.

The advice in the book is mostly practical and realistic.

It captured that learning from those who have walked through the career maze is essential for scaling the career ladder.

It also reveals how you can be proactive and confident in decision making and also how to build your home simultaneously. Effective multitasking is possible only when you have a clear sense of your priorities.

Breaking the barriers in your mind and building yourself to sit at the table requires a confidence, zeal, intellectual depth, honest regular self-evaluation and humility to learn from others.

Can women have it all? Maybe not, but, according to Olumide-Ojo, they can have all that matters to them by making choices that align with their personal goals.

groups.name: Movie Club
groups.description: Join this group to be part of our movie hang out and discussions. In this group, we suggest Movies,Music Videos and connect each and every 9to5 Chick movie lovers all around the World.

groupPost.text:
Movie lovers gather round!!
How was your Monday? Using a movie title describe how your Monday went. We can’t wait to know!

Open Cheque!😉

If you could have a date with a movie star(any gender) who would you pick?

Mention in the comments 👇🏻

5 Movies Every Career Woman Should Watch

The movie industry is focusing more and more on making movies that have an impact on the society. 


Art imitates life and as it turns out life imitates art too. Here’s a list of 5 movies you should watch



1.The Devil Wears Prada

Because Miranda Priestly rules in a man's world. And Andrea Sachs is her perfect foil. You can pick either side and not regret it because they both hold their own. It also helps that the movie is very funny and the fashion game is on point.


2. Shirley:

Despair, desire, and madness are all entangled in Josephine Decker’s Shirley, about the late horror writer Shirley Jackson’s (Elisabeth Moss) attempt to pen her sophomore novel Hangsaman while dealing with her unfaithful critic/professor husband Stanley Edgar Hyman (Michael Stuhlbarg) as well as two boarders, aspiring academic Fred (Logan Lerman) and his pregnant wife Rose (Odessa Young).


3.Gone With The Wind: If you need to pick one movie that revolves around the will to survive and prosper, then there is hardly any movie that does more justice than Gone With The World . It is the story of a woman, Scarlett O'Hara versus the swiftly-changing world. Scarlett wins. And how!


4. 9to5. This is a very old movie. Office satire about three female secretaries who decide to get revenge on their tyrannical, sexist boss by abducting him and running the business themselves. The trio, one of whom has been passed over for promotion because she is a woman, spend a night together having drug-induced fantasies of killing the slave-driving chauvinist. One of them panics the following day when she suspects she really has poisoned the tyrant.


5. Million Dollar Baby


Million Dollar Baby throws every stereotype about a girl to the wind. It also rightfully tells us that our age might only slow us down physically, but not our spirit. Because Maggie Fitzgerald tells us that dreams are not bound by limits.



What movies do you recommend?


P.S Our movie night holds on saturday by 8pm

Here's what is trending in Nigeria on Netflix.
Which of these movies have you seen or plan to see?

Ok! If you could have a date with a movie character who would it be?
You can add jara by sharing with us what you might discuss with the person.

Tell us in the comments.

Where are our movie lovers??
This Saturday we show up together at our virtual cinema!
Who is ready? What movie do you want to see?

Lessons From The Movie Self Made- Inspired by the life of Madam CJ Walker.

Watch time: 4 series at approximately 45 minutes each.


It's not very often that an entrepreneur's movie influence can still be used in the career space, but that is the case for Madam C.J. Walker.


Walker, born Sarah Breedlove in 1867 in Louisiana, is remembered today as the first black self-made female millionaire in the United States, amassing her fortune thanks to her groundbreaking haircare products for women of color and finely honed marketing skills.


From clothes washer to hairdresser, it wasn’t long before Madam’s legacy was planted, as she soon became America’s first self-made, African-American female millionaire.

1. Always Keep Your Eyes on the Prize

2. It’s Okay If Your Seed Takes a Little Longer to Grow

3. Don’t Forget to Smell the Flowers While You Still Can.

4. Let Your Haters Motivate You as Much as Those Who Love You

5. Remember Those Who Helped You Up When You Were Down.

6.Take Action on Strategic growth.

7. Have a clear big vision and light a match under it.

8. Women must invest in Women.

9. Tell your story and make it personal.

10. Be confident


What were some of your takeaways after watching Self Made: Inspired by the Life of Madam C.J. Walker? Let us know in the comments!
Help us have a good list of movies. What is your top 3 movies?

My Top Five Nigerian Movies on Netflix (and what I like about them)⁣

⁣

⁣
If you are one of those who say "I don't watch Nigerian movies", please shift 🙄 You don't watch Nigerian movies as per we should give you award of what? 🙄🙄🙄⁣
⁣
⁣
1. Elevator Baby 9/10⁣
Ahhhhh, I loved it like MAD. My best actor was @_timini. HE WAS TOO REAL. I do not think I have seen anyone realer in a movie before. My goodness. The humour was 🔥 Theme and setting of the movie? They tried abeg!⁣
⁣
⁣
2. Sugar Rush 7/10⁣
I had finished laughing before I started thinking about questions much after I had seen the movie. But I loved it! The lineup of actors lasan 🔥 It was the first time I was seeing @bimboademoye in a movie and she wowed me! I laughed gan o. I'm not going to raise any criticisms because the movie made me laugh. And ah, I LOVED THE COMFORTABLE INCLUSION OF YORUBA.⁣
⁣
⁣
3. Kasanova 7/10⁣
There was one major reason I loved the movie. It was lovey-mushy but it was so realistic. It's not everyday you have movies portray our older daddies and mummies falling head over heels over each other. So this one, I was just awwning all over the place 😭😭 @iretidoyle's performance was stellar. Can't remember the name of the girl who played her daughter but she was so fine. And Wale Ojo was 🔥🔥⁣
⁣
⁣
4. The Bridge (8/10)⁣
Ah, this one made me cry at the end. The love portrayed at the beginning was so pure. Chidinma on a movie? You don't see that everyday, guys! But tribalism made the two key actors die for nothing at the end. And that hit me so hard. Tina Mba and Ayo Mogaji were wonderful. It was great to see Zack Orji on a movie too.⁣
⁣
⁣
5. Hire a Woman (6/10)⁣
Hmmm, when I first saw this title, I thought it was a feminist movie o. That's how I went to watch it. I'm glad I wasn't disappointed 😂⁣
@nancyisimeofficial won my heart in this movie, let me not lie. Her acting was soooo relatable. Ah, as a person who doesn't take nonsense, I felt like I had seen a sister 😂😂😂 I loved the story of love in the movie but I also loved that it made me laugh! They should have used another title sha because that title no enter. ⁣

Credit: Orifunke Lawal.
⁣
⁣Which of these have you seen? What movie do you think we should see together? Let me hear from you in the comments.
Whether it's the Netflix style, YouTube or streaming for any platform,what's the one movie you can't stop watching?

WHAT YOU SHOULD NEVER WEAR TO WORK!
1. Dirty or wrinkled clothes!
2. Clothes that show too much skin
3. Too much jewelry or accessories
4. Messy hair 🤦🏻‍♀️
5. Dramatic Makeup
6. Very long nail art
7. Flip flops aka bathroom slippers


What are the other things you are not expected/cannot wear to work?

Work style tips for the week.


Whoop whoop! We are prepping for a mega week!! Happy Sunday.

Here are some work style tips to slay this week.


Organize and Edit Your Closet: This is essential. How can you create a great outfit if you can’t even see what you own? Start by decluttering your wardrobe.


Then, organize the remaining items neatly into categories. Hang what should be hung and fold the rest. Also, invest in a shoe rack so that you can easily visualize complete outfits. After doing so, your closet will feel much more inspiring, and you’ll fix those “nothing to wear” moments.


Invest in Styles that Work for Your Shape

This requires strategic shopping. In particular, investing in designs that work for your body shape is essential. If you don’t know the kind of dress that suits you pay attention to compliments and how you feel wearing a type of cloth and then invest more in those type. Just experiment, knowing that you look great regardless.


Feel confident:

Oh well no matter how great your cloth is if you don’t feel and act great then it doesn’t matter.  Whether on a Power pants,skip skirts or even home cloth be confident in your carriage.


What style tips can you give? Share


P.S which of the pictures will you rock best? 

#officeinspiration #workstyletips

Hey Triber ❤️

Imagine this was before you and you are asked to take anything out of the blessing before thee,what will you take out?

HOME MADE JUICES YOU SHOULD TRY OUT

Hello FD club! How’s your food game coming? 

Today, let’s talk about juicing. How many of us have gotten into juicing yet? If you haven’t, you should try it! It’s a fun and tasty way to pack a ton of healthy nutrients into a drinkable treat that’ll make you feel great.

Note: Do not use fruit or vegetable juices as a replacement for food.

1. The Green Goddess: This contains cucumber, apple and celery. This juice is super refreshing and hydrating.

2. Antioxidant Blast: This contains blueberry,beer and strawberry.

3. Immune Boosters: This contains Orange, ginger and lemon. Feeling under the weather? Send a power boost to your immune system with the germ-fighting combo of lemon, orange, and ginger.

4. Kale Kickstart: This contains kale, orange, banana, strawberry. Start your day off right with this fruity juice packed fruits and veggies!

5. Tropi Kale: This contains  banana, pineapple and Kale. Get your nutrients from dark, leafy greens all while drinking juice that tastes like the tropics! This is one of the juice recipes that is not recommended for centrifugal juicers.

Which of these would you be trying soon? And can you recommend your fave juices?

Homemade dishes you should try.


We hear this a lot, “ I don’t know what to cook, Food options are limited in Nigeria”. Well, here are 10 great dishes you could try.


1Jollof rice, of course this is number one (wink). No list of Nigerian foods can be complete without a mention of Jollof rice.


2 Akara(fried bean cake).


3 Dodo(deep fried plantain).


4 Beef Stew(can go with any type of rice).


5 Ewa Agoyin (Mashed steamed beans with pepper sauce.)


6 Ofada stew(can go with any type of rice).


7 Moimoi (steamed bean cake).


Erm… fill up the remaining 3. You could also please share with us your recipe for any of the above mentioned dishes.
This should be fun, Let's go 😃

Five Healthy Snack ideas

Working from home has increased the love of snacks for many persons, do you agree?

Here, are healthy snack ideas that can help you stay on track with your fitness goals.



Dark Chocolate

Are you surprised? Don’t be! Dark chocolate contains the fibre, iron,magnesium etc.Choose brands that are low in sugar and at least 70% dark.


Groundnuts and other nuts.

Nuts are another healthy snack idea! When choosing nuts, pick fresh, unsalted nuts.


Kilishi or Suya

Ok, you didn’t see this one coming. If you’re a meat eater, kilishi and suya make wonderful snacks!They are a great source of protein, very satisfying and minimally processed if you make them yourself at home or trust who makes it.


Fruits

Bananas, apples, oranges, grapes – nature has us covered! 

There are lots of snacks to choose from.

Find out which fruits you like best and always have them handy.

You can even try your hands on making some fruit salad if you’re feeling extra creative.


Smoothies!

Smoothies are one of the absolute best healthy snack ideas because you can get very creative.You can make a spinach smoothie to sneak in some veggies.

You can make a mango smoothie if that’s more your jam.

You can get extremely creative with smoothies. So have fun with it!


What’s your favorite healthy snack?

Let us know.

Breakfast inspiration.
Yay or nay?

Making money and creating wealth is a must have skill!


Don’t play the wrong games with money, understand it is a tool and this is a great mindset in creating wealth.


What is one of the best money advice you have gotten?

What Is Money Stopping You From Doing Right Now?


If you have,let’s say Two million dollars what is the first thing you would do?😎

#MoneyMonday

Happy Monday everyone!


As we get ready to make the most of this week do not forget that Financial peace isn't the acquisition of stuff.


It's learning to live on less than you make, so you can give money back and have money to invest.


You can't really win until you do this.


It is not the man who has too little, but the man who craves more, that is poor.


You must gain control over your money or the lack of it will forever control you.


Enjoy a moneyful week.
I recently started taking investment seriously, when I realized that saving cannot make one become rich. I started with stocks and crypto. Do you invest? What tips can you share?
Share Your Best Saving Tips With Us.

Why You Need An Emergency Fund


Your emergency fund covers you in the event of an unexpected financial blow, and can help prevent you from going into debt. It also provides peace of mind if you lose your job, become too ill to work or have to cover a major car or home repair.


Ok, God forbid! But I mean, you should have an emergency fund for real.

It is easier to pay extra money on debt right away when you have a cushion for unexpected expenses.


Although it may seem like a sacrifice, setting aside money in an emergency fund can provide you with true peace of mind and help you move more gracefully through otherwise stressful situations. It allows you to focus on taking care of the problem at hand without the additional worry about finances during a crisis. The sooner you start on your emergency fund, the sooner you can take advantage of these benefits.



Before you start an emergency fund you should have a savings goal 


A common recommendation is to to build your emergency fund to cover at least three to six months of expenses. However, if that seems daunting, then you can start with a smaller, more attainable goal.


Once you set your initial savings goal and set up an account, it's time to build up your emergency fund. There are different strategies you can use to start doing it.


You can work with your financial institution to set up automatic transfers from your checking account to your savings. You can also commit to contributing to your emergency when you receive sums of money outside of your usual income, such as gifts, bonuses etc.



Was this helpful? Do you have an emergency fund? How do you commit to it?

Three Books On Money Every Woman Should Read



When it comes to information on money and investing, it can feel like there is little or no information out there. Here are power books to read to make massive money move.


Smart Money Woman(1 & 2) by Arese Ugwu:

In this book you will Meet Zuri. She’s living a fabulous life. Great car, gorgeous apartment, well paid job.

With her best friends Tami (the flighty fashion designer), Lara (the tough oil and gas executive), Adesuwa (the conservative lawyer), and Ladun (the fabulous housewife), Zuri grows a little, learns a lot and navigates her way to making better financial decisions and building wealth.

This book tackles, debt, spending, the consumerist culture of the African middle class, the fear and misconceptions surrounding money and the lack of it, love, friendships, cultural and societal pressures and the roles they play in success.


A-Z of Personal Finance by Nimi Akinkugbe.

This is a very good read covering several topics on finances. She breaks down in simple terms some financial terms that usually is scary and what you need to do about it in your life.


The Richer Woman by Omilola Oshikoya.

It is a book chronicling her journey to being the richer woman, despite having a great job in the investment banking sector. But despite ‘all that money’, she struggled to find peace until she surrendered to a different way of thinking about how to be the ‘richer woman’.  The great thing about this book is, it can liberate you from the imbalance that comes with pursuing money at all costs and the temptations that come with it. If you are struggling with this or know someone who is, here is a book that can help you.



Aside these, there are a lot of books you can read this year to improve your finances if you take the time. Cheers to winning our money game!

Share Your Best Saving Tips With Us.

Who is the first to share? 💃💃
Let's go 🤑🤑🤑
Let's help a sister, what advice would you give?

groups.name: Career Tips
groups.description: Want easy to implement career tips to grow your career? Then join this group.

groupPost.text:
Leaders spin change and challenges into opportunities.
What is that one thing you would do next week for 15 minutes a day that would make all the difference? 

Enjoy a fab weekend, tribers.

Share the best career advice you have received(bonus point if you can do it in 6 words!)

Someone will be inspired,share below.
Building support systems is key for succeeding at work...what support systems do you need to grow in your career?

What narratives, expectations or myths have kept you feeling stuck? Share below!

Here are some.
-If I JUST work hard and remain committed I will have a very successful career.

-If I follow my career path, I will be fulfilled.

- Getting a high paying job will make me feel good about myself.

- My boss will ‘notice’ my good work and have me in mind for promotion.

5ways to deal with a difficult boss.


There's nothing more debilitating than heading into work every day depressed at the thought of having to face your boss. Have you been in this situation? How did you handle it? Here are 5tips to handle this situation.


1. Assess the situation. Do you have any level of responsibility for the damaged relationship, or does your boss have a negative relationship with everyone at work? Is your boss guilty of bad workplace behaviors in general, or does their behaviour seem to be directed at just you? When you are clear on what the situation is about you can be more intentional about your response.


2. Decide if it's bad enough to leave. It's one thing to struggle with a bad boss. It's a whole other circle of hell to be stuck in a mire of unhappy, dithering uncertainty about what to do about it.If issues with your boss run so deep as to be all-consuming, it's probably time to move on because it could affect your productivity.


3. If you're staying, stay positive. Assuming your boss issues are painful but not all-consuming, it may well be possible to stay and carve out a perfectly acceptable working environment, but only if you build on the right foundation. So if you've made a decision to stay, make a conscious commitment to staying positive. Don't dwell on the things your boss does that infuriate you, and don't take part in any of the office negativity surrounding your boss.


4. Vent your frustrations, but not to your colleagues. Dealing with a less-than-stellar boss on the daily can really wear you down. Opening up to a trusted friend or family member can help alleviate some of that stress. Not only will it help you get things off your chest, but they may be able to offer you a different perspective about the situation and what is really going on. And remember… Ask someone whose opinion you have the utmost respect for. The last thing you need is fuel to your fire.


5. Don’t burn bridges. You never know when you might need this person as a reference—many prospective employers ask specifically if they can contact your direct supervisor from your previous jobs, and having to respond “no” will raise red flags and will require an awkward explanation. As difficult as it might be, make sure you don’t allow the dynamic to compromise your professional reputation. Be tactful.


Ultimately, only you will know the best way to handle the situation. Have a heart-to-heart with yourself. Is the stress and tension of the situation worth it? Is it affecting your work? Can you adjust your behavior?



We hope these tips were helpful? What stood out more for you and what advice can you give to anyone in this situation.

It’s a new week! We look forward to sunshine and sweetness.

Here’s 4 ways to handle overwhelm and keep feeling energized through out the week!
• Allow yourself to feel your feelings
• Surround yourself with people who support you!( right in this community, we support you).
•Rest!!
• Have fun too

Career Hack of the Day: 


Our career hack of the day is taken straight from our webinar with Coach FAA on navigating office politics.


Identify your allies, stakeholders and key players at work and engage them early. It is not only when you have problems you meet them. 


Who are your workplace allies? Write down 5 of them and create a plan to start engaging with them. 


Don’t forget to say hi to your level up buddy and share how your day went on the app. We are a support system.



Good evening.
What are the biggest challenges in HR?
What's the best career advice you have ever received?

Setting career goals is like setting a map before the trip. Without a map, there is a good chance you will get lost or spend your quality time wandering. Below are practically steps you can take towards setting you career goals


1. Reflect and evaluate.

 Review your career performance against the goals you set out for yourself at the beginning of the year. Update your LinkedIn to reflect your growth or accomplishments, congratulate yourself and decide to do more. 

2. Take note of unaccomplished goals and challenges: Understanding the challenges and road blocks of unaccomplished goals and this will equip you with knowledge to achieve more.

3. Research your future role: Nothing is constant in career development. Understand how your role may look like in future and research skills you may need.

4. Identify personal areas of improvement: find out the personal weaknesses that may impede your career growth. Ask your boss or colleagues to learn what areas you need improvement. 

5. Set realistic goals: Do a reality check on your goals by ensuring that your activities will be specific and achievable.

6.Have a plan and time frame: Plan the necessary steps, resources, and time frame that you need to achieve them

7. Review and update your goals: Realise that you may run into road blocks but don't let it stop you. Change the activities if they are not working, take a different action and understand that career are a long life journey.

Do not forget to celebrate your progress and share with us on #9to5chick.


Have you set your goals to enable tracking on the web app yet?


We are here to support you all the way through 🙌😍
Had any career breakthrough? Tell us about it.
Share your tips with your fellow 9to5 Chick members.

groups.name: Travel
groups.description: Traveling is a whole learning experience. Right in this group we will be sharing travel fascinating tips and guides,discounts and travel opportunities.

groupPost.text:
Great Places To Visit in Nigeria

  1. Obudu cattle ranch
  2. YanKari Games reserve
  3. Ikogosi Warm Spring Resort
  4. Owu waterfall
  5. Takwa Bay, Lagos


Do you have a favourite family vacation destination? Tell us in the comments below

List 5 cities that have the first letter of your name.


An example for the letter A: Anthens, Abu Dhabi, Addis Ababa,Amsterdam, Alaska...

Now bring it on! How well do you know the cities of the world.

5 cities that should be on your travel list.


I admit, there are several amazing cities in the world. But for the purpose of this post we will restrict it to 5 cities. 

1. Bali, Indonesia: "You’ll find beaches, volcanoes, Komodo dragons and jungles sheltering elephants, orangutans and tigers. Basically, it’s paradise.


2. The Maldives: "This tropical nation in the Indian Ocean is made up of more than 1,000 coral islands. It’s home to some of the world’s most luxurious hotel resorts, with white sandy beaches, underwater villas and restaurants and bright blue waters."


3.Florence, Italy

Florence is the birthplace of the Renaissance and has the art and architecture to prove it, but beyond that it maintains a large European city feel on a small walkable scale


4. Istanbul, Turkey

There are countless reasons to visit Istanbul: the hills; the Bosphorus; the Blue Mosque; Hagia Sofia; the Grand Bazaar; its amazing history and importance on the Silk Road. And everything comes together magnificently. 


5. Sydney, Australia

Australia is the number one dream destination of Americans. Stop dreaming and go!


If you were given an all-expense trip opportunity which of these cities would you go to? Tell us.
We really cannot wait to tour...
Long time no travel.

Love to go mountain climbing in Rwanda,sky diving in SANTA BARBARA, CALIFORNIA or...
Let us know your thoughts!
Do you have a self care routine? Share with the tribe
Want to have of maintain a gorgeous skin? See this👇
What's your best method of moisturizing your skin?

Let’s Get Into Some Self-Care Tips.

Self-care doesn’t have to mean spending thousands of dollars on skin creams, fitness classes, and other 'experiences'.

Sure, there’s meditation and green juice, and all the routines but sometimes, self-care is the little ways we find joy in day-to-day life, and take a step back to exhale.

Self-care can be as easy as telling yourself, “I am powerful,” every morning. Or, it can be as involved as finally picking apart your finances and rebuilding them from the bottom up.  

Self care helps you make Power Moves in every aspect of your life. 
What are some of your self-care tips? Share with us.
Welcome to the ask me anything session with today's guest, Mofoluwaso Ilevbare- Hr Director PandG. Scroll down to the 3rd post to join the conversation.

Loving this app. Looking forward to networking with you, Ladies. Feel free to ask me any questions beyond the topic. 

Virtual Hugs,
Fofo

Are you looking to get a job in a multinational company? Then don’t miss this webinar!
Happening right here in this group (in the previous post).
Time:9am
Start dropping in your questions.

Meet our guest for our first ASK ME ANYTHING SESSION happening on Saturday by 9am right here on this group. Get your questions ready!


Mofoluwaso Ilevbare (a.k.a. Fofo) is currently the Head of HR,  Procter & Gamble Australia & New Zealand. She has over 19 years experience as an HR Thought Leader, Executive Coach, and Trainer in the pharmaceutical, manufacturing, hospitality management, leadership coaching, and nonprofit sectors. 


Having worked and lived across 4 continents, being a wife, mom, lover of God and all things chocolate, Fofo is a passionate advocate for more women in the boardroom.


Her mission is about raising Esthers and Mordecais in the Workplace and local communities who are unstoppable at work and balanced in life and she shares this passion in and out of the workplace as a speaker, multi award winning author, trainer, and volunteer-mentor in many organizations such as WIMBIZ, FATE Foundation, Cherie Blair Women, Queens Young Leaders etc.


Mofoluwaso has a Bachelor of Pharmacy degree, an MBA with specialization in HR Management, a certified Executive & Leadership Coach with LHH, John Maxwell, and ICA. She’s a Fellow of the Institute of Management Consultants, SHRM-SCP certified, HRCI-GPHR certified, certifications in Culture Transformation, Social and Emotional Intelligence etc. 


Together with partners, Fofo sits on the board of several initiatives that inspire women and girls, young professionals, university students, orphanages, to live their dreams and be unstoppable! Such platforms include Women Connected by Purpose, Thrive in Heels and Flourishing40s Network, to mention a few. 


She's received several local and global awards for her work in HR and Women Leadership advocacy and is featured in the media from time to time. 


Her favourite mantra is to "Fear Less, Press Forward, and BE UNSTOPPABLE"  and her favourite scriptures are Rom 8:28./Dan 11:32b


Follow Fofo @mofoluwasoilevbare on Instagram, visit her website  https:// mofoluwaso.com, and download her MOFOLUWASO mobile app for inspiration on the go!

groups.name: Speed Networking
groups.description:
We are bringing international experts to drive the networking session happening on the 9th of September,2020 by 6pm

We have none other than Bukola Adisa, Founder of Career Masterclass and Former MD,Control and Framework Design & Execution Lead, Barclays and Karen Mwendera South African award-winning journalist based in South Africa & curator of the Forbes Africa 30 under 30. 

Come with your questions on building visibility, climbing the corporate ladder, building relationship or any other career related subject.

groupPost.text: It is almost time! Ladies get ready...
Grab your cups of coffee, a meal or two, and see you all at 6. Looking forward to engaging with you all!

Welcome to our first Ask Me Anything Session, we have none other than Karen Mwendera South African award-winning journalist based in South Africa & curator of the Forbes Africa 30 under 30.

Ask your questions, connect and network in the comment!

Welcome to the first Ask Me Anything Session, we have none other than Bukola Adisa, Founder of Career Masterclass and Former MD, Control and Framework Design & Execution Lead, Barclays.

Ask your questions, connect and network in the comment!

Meet out one of our facilitator for the speed networking program happening this evening by 6pm.

Get your questions ready on anything career, international opportunities and building great relationships.

Karen Mwendera is an award-winning journalist based in South Africa and a journalism and media studies lecturer. She the curator of the Forbes Africa 30 under 30 lists bringing together game changers from across the continent in business, sports, tech and creatives fields. She has worked with numerous local and international publications and has interviewed the likes of Naomi Campbell, President of the AfDB Akinwumi Adesina, Naspers CEO Phuti Mahenyele, Danai Gurira, Femi Kuti, Yvonne Chaka Chaka, Mr Eazi, President Cyril Ramaphosa and more.

"Growing up in four different African countries I consider every part of Africa home. Storytelling is in my blood and I am passionate about telling positive authentic African stories."

Meet out one of our facilitator for the speed networking program happening this evening by 6pm.

Get your questions ready on anything career, international opportunities and building great relationships.

Bukola is a Risk and Controls executive who has held senior roles at some of the world’s largest financial services organisations. In her last role, she was a Managing Director and Head of Framework, Design and Execution within the Barclays Chief Controls Office. In this role, Bukola was responsible for the enterprise wide design and execution of the Risk and Controls Assessment process, ensuring that Barclays operates a very robust controls environment.

Prior to this role, she was the Europe Head of Regulatory Compliance Monitoring and Testing at HSBC. In that role, she was responsible for a regional team of 110 professionals who conducted regulatory reviews to ensure that the bank was compliant with relevant regulations across all lines of business. 

Bukola also worked at RBS where she led the Financial Crime Assurance team globally. While at RBS, she was promoted three times in 18 months. She has also spent time at JP Morgan Chase and Deloitte LLP where she advised top tier banking clients on regulatory matters.

She is passionate about the progression of women and BAME professionals in the workplace. At each organisation Bukola has worked at, she has been an active member of the Women’s network as well as the Multicultural or BAME networks. She actively mentors BAME professionals and dedicates many hours monthly to providing career advice and encouragement to them. She also actively sponsors the careers of a number of high potential BAME professionals and has created and provided promotion opportunities for them when that would not have otherwise been possible

Bukola is also the Founder/CEO of Career Masterclass which is a leading online career development platform focused on enabling the career growth of ambitious professionals by teaching the practical skills that they can use to build and enjoy a successful career.  

To date, Career Masterclass has positively impacted the lives of 1000s of professionals, running a programme of webinars, talks and other event and by providing online courses through their dynamic learning platform called STRETCH Academy. Career Masterclass also hosts an annual career development conference called STRETCH Conference to inspire and provide career development opportunities for aspirational BAME professionals,

She was recently listed in the 2018, 2019 and 2020 PowerList which celebrates the achievements of senior professionals from an African and Caribbean background. She was also listed in the 2017 Empower Financial Times List of the top 100 Ethnic Minorities in the United Kingdom and was named in the Financial Times HERoes list of the executives who have made a substantial difference to women’s careers.

Bukola was also the 2016 winner of the PRECIOUS Awards Outstanding woman in banking and finance and was listed in Brummells magazine as one of the 30 most inspirational women working in the city of London.
